meta.dc:subject: legislation
meta.dc:rights: The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

main.longTitle: An Ordinance to implement the Minamata Convention on Mercury; to regulate the export, import, keeping and use of mercury, mercury mixtures and mercury compounds; to control the export, import, manufacture and supply of certain mercury-added products; to control certain manufacturing processes in which mercury or mercury compounds are used; and to provide for related matters.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Mercury Control Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.def: air transhipment cargo (航空轉運貨物) has the meaning given by section 2 of the Import and Export Ordinance (Cap. 60);
article in transit (過境物品) has the meaning given by section 2 of the Import and Export Ordinance (Cap. 60);
authorized officer (獲授權人員) means a public officer authorized under section 72;
Convention (《公約》) means the Minamata Convention on Mercury adopted by the Conference of Plenipotentiaries on 10 October 2013 in Japan, as amended from time to time and as applied to Hong Kong;
Director (署長) means the Director of Environmental Protection;
export permit (出口許可證) means a permit issued under section 18, or such a permit issued on renewal under section 27, and that is in force;
function (職能) includes a power and a duty;
import permit (進口許可證) means a permit issued under section 20, or such a permit issued on renewal under section 27, and that is in force;
mercury (汞) means elemental mercury (Hg(0), Chemical Abstracts Service registry number 7439-97-6);

mercury compound (汞化合物) means a substance—(a)that can be separated into different components only by chemical reactions; and(b)that consists of—(i)atoms of mercury; and(ii)one or more atoms of other chemical elements;
mercury mixture (汞混合物) means a mixture, having a mercury concentration of at least 95% by weight, of mercury and other substances (including alloys of mercury);
mercury-added product (添汞產品)—see section 3(1);
Part 1 chemical (第1部化學品) means a chemical specified in Part 1 of Schedule 1, other than that contained in a mercury-added product;
Part 2 chemical (第2部化學品) means a chemical specified in Part 2 of Schedule 1, other than that contained in a mercury-added product;
possession permit (管有許可證) means a permit issued under section 22, or such a permit issued on renewal under section 27, and that is in force;
prescribed fee (訂明費用), in relation to a matter specified in column 2 of Schedule 4, means the fee specified in column 3 of that Schedule opposite the matter;
regulated manufacturing process (受規管製造工序) means a process falling within a description in column 2 of Schedule 2;
regulated mercury-added product (受規管添汞產品)—see section 3(2);
regulatory requirement (規管性規定) means a requirement under—(a)this Ordinance;(b)a condition imposed under this Ordinance; or(c)a direction given under section 39;
Secretary (局長) means the Secretary for Environment and Ecology; (Amended L.N. 144 of 2022)

supply (供應) means to supply (whether through the Internet or a similar electronic network or otherwise) with or without payment, and includes offering or exhibiting (whether through the Internet or a similar electronic network or otherwise) for the purpose of such supplying;
transport (交通工具) means a vehicle, train, vessel, aircraft or any other means of transport;

type (類別)—(a)in relation to Part 1 chemicals—means a type of Part 1 chemical specified in column 2 of Part 1 of Schedule 1; and(b)in relation to Part 2 chemicals—means a type of Part 2 chemical specified in column 2 of Part 2 of Schedule 1.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Meaning of mercury-added product and regulated mercury-added product

subsection.content: In this Ordinance, a mercury-added product is a thing that contains intentionally added mercury or mercury compounds, irrespective of whether the thing is to be further incorporated into another thing as a component.
In this Ordinance, a regulated mercury-added product is a mercury-added product falling within a description in column 2 of Part 1 of Schedule 3.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, as long as a regulated mercury-added product (component part) is incorporated into another thing (main body) that is not by itself a regulated mercury-added product as a component—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the component part is regarded as not being a regulated mercury-added product;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the main body does not become a regulated mercury-added product merely because it has a component part incorporated into it; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the component part and the main body as a whole are regarded as a mercury-added product.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Presumptions concerning Part 1 chemical, Part 2 chemical and regulated mercury-added product

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Ordinance, if any of the relevant materials of a thing shows that the thing falls within a description in column 2 of Part 1 of Schedule 1, the thing is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, presumed to be a Part 1 chemical.

For the purposes of this Ordinance, if any of the relevant materials of a thing shows that the thing falls within a description in column 2 of Part 2 of Schedule 1, the thing is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, presumed to be a Part 2 chemical.

For the purposes of this Ordinance and subject to section 3(3), if any of the relevant materials of a thing shows that the thing falls within a description in column 2 of Part 1 of Schedule 3, the thing is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, presumed to be a regulated mercury-added product.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant materials (相關材料), in relation to a thing, means—(a)labels or packaging of the thing; or(b)other documents, provided by the manufacturer, importer, exporter or supplier of the thing, containing information, descriptions or statements about the thing.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Ordinance applies to Government

subsection.content: This Ordinance applies to the Government.
The Government is not liable to be prosecuted for an offence under this Ordinance.
An act done, or omitted to be done, by a public officer in good faith in performing or purportedly performing a function under this Ordinance does not constitute an offence under this Ordinance.
No prescribed fee is payable by the Government.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Ordinance does not apply to certain mercury etc.
section.leadIn: This Ordinance does not apply in relation to mercury, mercury mixtures, mercury compounds or mercury-added products falling within any of the following descriptions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: pesticide as defined by section 2 of the Pesticides Ordinance (Cap. 133);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: waste as defined by section 2 of the Waste Disposal Ordinance (Cap. 354);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Chinese herbal medicine as defined by section 2 of the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: article in transit;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: thing that is, or is a part of, an air transhipment cargo;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: thing that is brought into Hong Kong by a person who—

subparagraph.content: arrives at the Hong Kong International Airport from a place outside Hong Kong solely for the purpose of leaving Hong Kong; and
does not pass through immigration control while in Hong Kong.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Ordinance does not apply to mercury etc. of trace quantity
section.leadIn: This Ordinance does not apply in relation to mercury, mercury mixtures or mercury compounds falling within any of the following descriptions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: naturally occurring trace quantities of mercury or mercury compound present in any of the following or in the products derived from any of the following—

subparagraph.content: non-mercury metals;
non-mercury ores;
non-mercury mineral products (such as coal);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: unintentional trace quantities of mercury or mercury compound present in a chemical product.

part.name: P2
part.heading: Prohibitions relating to Part 1 Chemical, Part 2 Chemical, Regulated Mercury-added Product and Regulated Manufacturing Process

section.name: s8
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 1 of Part 2
section.def: medical establishment (醫療機構) means—(a)a private healthcare facility within the meaning of the Private Healthcare Facilities Ordinance (Cap. 633) for which a licence under that Ordinance is in force;(b)a scheduled nursing home within the meaning of the Private Healthcare Facilities Ordinance (Cap. 633) for which an exemption granted under section 128 of that Ordinance is in force;(c)a nursing home within the meaning of the Residential Care Homes (Elderly Persons) Ordinance (Cap. 459);(d)a hospital, maternity home or clinic managed or controlled by the Hospital Authority established under the Hospital Authority Ordinance (Cap. 113);(e)a mental hospital within the meaning of the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136); or(f)premises used exclusively by any of the following persons in the course of the person’s practice on the person’s own account—(i)a registered medical practitioner within the meaning of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161);(ii)a registered dentist within the meaning of the Dentists Registration Ordinance (Cap. 156);(iii)a registered veterinary surgeon within the meaning of the Veterinary Surgeons Registration Ordinance (Cap. 529);

specified laboratory (指明實驗室) means—(a)a laboratory maintained by a medical establishment;(b)a laboratory maintained by a specified institution as defined by the Second Schedule to the Education Regulations (Cap. 279 sub. leg. A);(c)a science laboratory as defined by regulation 2 of the Education Regulations (Cap. 279 sub. leg. A);(d)a medical laboratory supervised by a registered medical laboratory technologist (within the meaning of the Medical Laboratory Technologists (Registration and Disciplinary Procedure) Regulations (Cap. 359 sub. leg. A)); or(e)a laboratory accredited under the Hong Kong Laboratory Accreditation Scheme managed by the Commissioner for Innovation and Technology on behalf of the Government.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Prohibition on export of Part 1 chemical

subsection.content: A person must not export Part 1 chemicals except under an export permit.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Part 1 chemical is exported for use for laboratory-scale research or as a reference standard;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the chemical, while being exported, is contained in packages or containers, and the total quantity of mercury in the type of chemical to which the chemical belongs in each package or container does not exceed 250 g; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the total quantity of mercury in that type of chemical to be exported in the shipment by the person does not exceed 5 kg.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Prohibition on import of Part 1 chemical

subsection.content: A person must not import Part 1 chemicals except under an import permit.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Part 1 chemical is imported for use for laboratory-scale research or as a reference standard;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the chemical, while being imported, is contained in packages or containers, and the total quantity of mercury in the type of chemical to which the chemical belongs in each package or container does not exceed 250 g; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the total quantity of mercury in that type of chemical to be imported in the shipment by the person does not exceed 5 kg.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Prohibition on keeping of Part 2 chemical

subsection.content: A person must not keep Part 2 chemicals except under a possession permit.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Part 2 chemical is kept in a specified laboratory for use for laboratory-scale research or as a reference standard; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the total quantity of mercury in the type of chemical to which the chemical belongs being kept in the laboratory does not exceed 500 g.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 2 or more separate specified laboratories are situated on the same floor of a building; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the operation of those laboratories is supervised by the same person (whether alone or jointly with another person),

subsection.continued: those laboratories are regarded as a single laboratory.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Prohibition on use of Part 2 chemical

subsection.content: A person must not use Part 2 chemicals except under a possession permit.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 11(1) does not apply to the keeping of the Part 2 chemical because of the operation of section 11(2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the chemical is used in a specified laboratory for laboratory-scale research or as a reference standard.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Prohibition on export of regulated mercury-added product

subsection.content: A person must not export regulated mercury-added products.
Subsection (1) does not apply if the regulated mercury-added product falls within a description in column 2 of Part 2 of Schedule 3.
A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Prohibition on import of regulated mercury-added product

subsection.content: A person must not import regulated mercury-added products.
Subsection (1) does not apply if the regulated mercury-added product falls within a description in column 2 of Part 2 of Schedule 3.
A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Prohibition on manufacture of regulated mercury-added product etc.

subsection.content: A person must not manufacture regulated mercury-added products.
Subsection (1) does not apply if the regulated mercury-added product under manufacture falls within a description in column 2 of Part 2 of Schedule 3.
A person must not incorporate a regulated mercury-added product into another thing as a component.
A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Prohibition on supply of regulated mercury-added product

subsection.content: A person must not supply regulated mercury-added products on or after the third anniversary of the commencement date* of this Ordinance.
A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Prohibition on carrying out regulated manufacturing process

subsection.content: A person must not carry out regulated manufacturing processes.
A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

part.name: P3
part.heading: Export Permit, Import Permit and Possession Permit

section.name: s18
section.heading: Export permit

subsection.content: A person may apply to the Director for an export permit in relation to the export of a batch of Part 1 chemicals.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, on the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issue an export permit to the applicant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse to issue an export permit on a ground specified in section 19.

subsection.leadIn: On issuing an export permit, the Director may impose conditions the Director considers appropriate, including conditions regulating matters concerning the carrying out of the export such as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which, or the period within which, the export may be carried out;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the manner in which the export is to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the place at which the batch of chemicals is to be loaded onto any transport for export.

subsection.leadIn: The following are to be specified in an export permit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the permit takes effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the validity period of the permit;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if conditions are imposed in respect of the permit under subsection (3)—the conditions.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Grounds for refusing to issue export permit
section.leadIn: The following grounds are specified for the purposes of section 18(2)(b) in relation to an application for an export permit to export a batch of Part 1 chemicals—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the relevant government authority of the place to which the batch of chemicals is proposed to be exported would allow the batch of chemicals to be imported;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that refusing the application is necessary for protecting the public health or environment.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Import permit

subsection.content: A person may apply to the Director for an import permit in relation to the import of a batch of Part 1 chemicals.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, on the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issue an import permit to the applicant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse to issue an import permit on a ground specified in section 21.

subsection.leadIn: On issuing an import permit, the Director may impose conditions the Director considers appropriate, including conditions regulating matters concerning the carrying out of the import such as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which, or the period within which, the import may be carried out;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the manner in which the import is to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the place at which the batch of chemicals is to be unloaded from any transport.

subsection.leadIn: The following are to be specified in an import permit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the permit takes effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the validity period of the permit;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if conditions are imposed in respect of the permit under subsection (3)—the conditions.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Grounds for refusing to issue import permit
section.leadIn: The following grounds are specified for the purposes of section 20(2)(b) in relation to an application for an import permit to import a batch of Part 1 chemicals—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that the batch of chemicals is to be imported solely for re-export;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the batch of chemicals, if imported, would be kept in an environmentally sound manner as required by the Convention;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the batch of chemicals, if imported, would be used for a purpose permitted under the Convention;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that refusing the application is necessary for protecting the public health or environment.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Possession permit

subsection.content: A person may apply to the Director for a possession permit in relation to the keeping and use of a batch of Part 2 chemicals.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, on the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issue a possession permit to the applicant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse to issue a possession permit on a ground specified in section 23.

subsection.leadIn: On issuing a possession permit, the Director may impose conditions the Director considers appropriate, including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: conditions regulating matters concerning the keeping of the batch of chemicals such as—

subparagraph.content: the place or premises at or on which the batch of chemicals is to be kept; and
the manner in which the batch of chemicals is to be kept; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: conditions regulating matters concerning the use of the batch of chemicals such as—

subparagraph.content: the purpose for which the batch of chemicals may be used; and
the manner in which the batch of chemicals is to be used.

subsection.leadIn: The following are to be specified in a possession permit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the permit takes effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the validity period of the permit;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if conditions are imposed in respect of the permit under subsection (3)—the conditions.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Grounds for refusing to issue possession permit
section.leadIn: The following grounds are specified for the purposes of section 22(2)(b) in relation to an application for a possession permit to keep and use a batch of Part 2 chemicals—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the applicant has the ability to keep the batch of chemicals in an environmentally sound manner as required by the Convention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the batch of chemicals would be used for a purpose permitted under the Convention;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that refusing the application is necessary for protecting the public health or environment.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Validity period of permit—export permit and import permit
section.leadIn: Unless suspended or cancelled under Division 3, an export permit or import permit is in force until—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the date on which, or the period within which, the export or import may be carried out under the permit is specified as a condition imposed under this Part in respect of the permit—the earliest of the following—

subparagraph.content: the export or import is carried out under the permit;
the expiry of the specified date;
the expiry of the specified period; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in any other case—the earlier of the following—

subparagraph.content: the export or import is carried out under the permit;
the expiry of 12 months (or if the Director specifies in the permit a shorter validity period, the shorter period) beginning on the date on which the permit takes effect.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Validity period of permit—possession permit
section.content: Unless suspended or cancelled under Division 3, a possession permit is in force until the expiry of 12 months (or if the Director specifies in the permit a shorter validity period, the shorter period) beginning on the date on which the permit takes effect.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Permit holder to comply with permit condition

subsection.content: The holder of an export permit, import permit or possession permit must comply with the conditions imposed under this Part in respect of the permit.
A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Renewal of permit

subsection.content: The holder of an export permit, import permit or possession permit may apply to the Director for renewal of the permit.
The application may only be made while the permit concerned is in force.

subsection.leadIn: If an export is carried out under an export permit while an application for renewing the permit is pending, the permit holder must, as soon as reasonably practicable after the export, by written notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the Director of the export; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: withdraw the application.

subsection.leadIn: If an import is carried out under an import permit while an application for renewing the permit is pending, the permit holder must, as soon as reasonably practicable after the import, by written notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the Director of the import; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: withdraw the application.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, on the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: renew the permit concerned; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: refuse to renew the permit if satisfied that—

subparagraph.content: for an application for renewal of an export permit—an export has been carried out under the permit;
for an application for renewal of an import permit—an import has been carried out under the permit; or
the refusal is necessary for protecting the public health or environment.

subsection.leadIn: On renewing a permit, the Director—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: may impose conditions the Director considers appropriate, including conditions mentioned in—

subparagraph.content: for an export permit—section 18(3);
for an import permit—section 20(3); or
for a possession permit—section 22(3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must issue a new permit to the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: The following are to be specified in a new permit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the permit takes effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the validity period of the permit;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if conditions are imposed in respect of the permit under subsection (6)(a)—the conditions.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Duplicate of permit

subsection.content: This section applies in relation to an export permit, import permit or possession permit that is lost, destroyed, defaced or damaged.
The holder of a permit (original permit) may apply to the Director for the issue of a duplicate of the original permit.
Without limiting Division 4, the application must be accompanied by the original permit unless the permit is lost.

subsection.leadIn: If an application is made in relation to a lost original permit, and the holder of the permit finds the lost permit while the application is pending, the holder must, as soon as reasonably practicable, by written notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the Director of this fact; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: withdraw the application.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, on the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: approve the application; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse the application.

subsection.content: On issuing a duplicate of an original permit, the original permit ceases to have effect.

subsection.leadIn: A duplicate of an original permit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has the same effect as the original permit for the remainder of the period for which the original permit would have remained in force but for subsection (6); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is to be regarded as having been issued under the same provision under which the original permit was issued or is regarded as having been issued.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 2 of Part 3
section.def: permit (許可證) means an export permit, import permit or possession permit.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Variation of permit condition on Director’s own initiative

subsection.content: The Director may, on the Director’s own initiative, at any time vary a condition (permit condition) imposed under this Part in respect of a permit if satisfied that the variation is necessary for protecting the public health or environment.

subsection.leadIn: If the Director intends to vary a permit condition, the Director must, by written notice, notify the permit holder of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the intention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds for the proposed variation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the holder’s right to make representations under subsection (3).

subsection.content: The permit holder may, within 28 days after the date of the written notice (or a longer period the Director allows), make representations in writing to the Director objecting to the proposed variation.
If representations are made under subsection (3), the Director may vary a permit condition only after considering those representations.

subsection.leadIn: The Director, once having decided to vary a permit condition, must, by written notice, notify the permit holder of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: how the permit condition is to be varied;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds for the variation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date on which the variation takes effect.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Variation of permit condition on application

subsection.content: The holder of a permit may apply to the Director for variation of a condition imposed under this Part in respect of the permit.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, on the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: approve the application; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse the application.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Supplementary provisions as to variation of permit condition

subsection.content: This section applies in relation to a permit (existing permit) any condition of which is varied under section 30 or 31.

subsection.leadIn: The holder of an existing permit must return the permit to the Director within 10 days after the later of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the holder’s receiving the written notice of the variation given under section 30(5) from the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date on which the variation takes effect.

subsection.leadIn: On receiving an existing permit returned under subsection (2), the Director must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issue a new permit to replace the existing permit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify in the new permit the conditions of the permit as varied.

subsection.leadIn: A new permit issued under subsection (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to the conditions of the permit as varied, has the same effect as the existing permit for the remainder of the period for which the existing permit would have remained in force but for the replacement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is to be regarded as having been issued under the same provision under which the existing permit was issued or is regarded as having been issued.

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 3 of Part 3
section.def: former permit holder (前許可證持有人), in relation to a permit cancelled under section 35, means the person who held the permit immediately before the cancellation;
permit (許可證) means an export permit, import permit or possession permit.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Suspension of permit
section.content: The Director may, on a ground specified in section 36, by order suspend a permit for the period specified by the Director in the order.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Cancellation of permit
section.content: The Director may, on a ground specified in section 36, by order cancel a permit.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Grounds for suspending or cancelling permit
section.leadIn: The following grounds are specified for the purposes of sections 34 and 35 in relation to a permit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the Director is satisfied that the permit holder has contravened—

subparagraph.content: this Ordinance; or
a condition imposed under this Part in respect of the permit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that the permit was obtained by fraud or misrepresentation;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the permit holder falls within any of the following descriptions—

subparagraph.content: for a permit holder that is a company—winding up proceedings have been commenced in relation to the permit holder or the permit holder has been dissolved;
for a permit holder that is a partnership—the permit holder has been dissolved;

for a permit holder that is an individual—the permit holder has died, has become bankrupt, or has entered into a voluntary arrangement within the meaning of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) with the holder’s creditors;
in any other case—the permit holder has ceased to exist;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that exercising the power under section 34 or 35 (as the case requires) is necessary for protecting the public health or environment.

section.name: s37
section.heading: Notice of intention to suspend or cancel permit etc.

subsection.leadIn: If the Director intends to suspend or cancel a permit under section 34 or 35, the Director must, by written notice, notify the permit holder of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the intention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds for the proposed suspension or cancellation;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date on which the suspension or cancellation is proposed to take effect;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for a suspension—the proposed period of suspension; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the holder’s right to make representations under subsection (2).

subsection.content: The permit holder may, within 28 days after the date of the written notice (or a longer period the Director allows), make representations in writing to the Director objecting to the proposed suspension or cancellation.
If representations are made under subsection (2), the Director may suspend or cancel a permit only after considering those representations.

subsection.leadIn: The Director, once having decided to suspend or cancel a permit, must, by written notice, notify the permit holder of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds for the suspension or cancellation;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date on which the suspension or cancellation takes effect; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for a suspension—the period of suspension.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Return of permit on its cancellation

subsection.content: If a permit is cancelled under section 35, the former permit holder must return the permit to the Director within 10 days after the date on which the cancellation takes effect.
A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Director may give disposal direction on cancellation

subsection.leadIn: If a permit is cancelled under section 35, the Director may, by written notice, give a direction to the former permit holder as to the disposal of the following things that are in Hong Kong and in the holder’s control or possession—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any chemicals that might be exported, imported, kept or used but for the cancellation of the permit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any thing that contains the chemicals.

subsection.leadIn: If the Director intends to give a direction under subsection (1), the Director must, by written notice, notify the former permit holder of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the intention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proposed direction;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the grounds for giving the direction;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the proposed period within which the direction is to be complied with; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the holder’s right to make representations under subsection (3).

subsection.content: The former permit holder may, within 28 days after the date of the written notice given under subsection (2) (or a longer period the Director allows), make representations in writing to the Director objecting to the proposed direction.
If representations are made under subsection (3), the Director may give a direction under subsection (1) only after considering those representations.

subsection.leadIn: The Director, once having decided to give a direction under subsection (1), must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by written notice notify the former permit holder of the direction; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: specify in the notice—

subparagraph.content: the grounds for giving the direction; and
the period within which the direction is to be complied with.

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a direction given under subsection (1) within the period specified under subsection (5) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Variation of disposal direction on application

subsection.content: A former permit holder may apply to the Director for variation of a direction given to the holder under section 39.
The application may only be made within 10 days after the date of the holder’s receiving the written notice given under section 39(5) from the Director.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, on the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: approve the application; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse the application.

division.name: D4
division.heading: General Provisions about Applications under this Part

section.name: s41
section.heading: Application of Division 4 of Part 3
section.content: This Division applies in relation to an application made under this Part.

section.name: s42
section.heading: How to make application

subsection.leadIn: An application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be in the specified form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by the information, documents and particulars specified in the specified form; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if not made by the Government—must be accompanied by the prescribed fee.

subsection.leadIn: For an application under section 31 to vary a condition imposed under this Part in respect of a permit, the applicant must state in the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: how the applicant would like the condition to be varied; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds for the proposed variation.

subsection.leadIn: For an application under section 40 to vary a direction, the applicant must state in the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: how the applicant would like the direction to be varied; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds for the proposed variation.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Director may require information etc. for determining application

subsection.content: For determining an application, the Director may require the applicant to provide further information, documents and particulars that are reasonably necessary to enable the Director to determine the application.

subsection.leadIn: If the applicant fails to comply with a requirement made under subsection (1), the Director—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may refuse to process the application further; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may refuse the application.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Notice of intention to refuse application

subsection.leadIn: If the Director intends to refuse an application, the Director must, by written notice, notify the applicant of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the intention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds for the proposed refusal; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the applicant’s right to make representations under subsection (2).

subsection.content: The applicant may, within 28 days after the date of the written notice (or a longer period the Director allows), make representations in writing to the Director objecting to the proposed refusal.
If representations are made under subsection (2), the Director may refuse the application only after considering those representations.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Notice of decision
section.leadIn: The Director must, by written notice, notify the applicant of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director’s decision on the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the Director approves an application under section 31 to vary a condition imposed under this Part in respect of a permit—

subparagraph.content: how the condition is to be varied; and
the date on which the variation takes effect;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the Director approves an application under section 40 to vary a direction—

subparagraph.content: how the direction is to be varied; and
the date on which the variation takes effect; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the Director refuses the application—the grounds for the refusal.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Interpretation of Part 4
section.def: premises (處所) includes any transport.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Limitation on exercise of power under Divisions 2 and 3
section.leadIn: Divisions 2 and 3 do not empower an authorized officer to exercise any of the powers under those Divisions in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an article in transit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an air transhipment cargo; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a thing falling within the description of section 6(f).

section.name: s48
section.heading: Power to inspect document and record kept under regulatory requirement etc.

subsection.leadIn: For ascertaining whether a regulatory requirement has been or is being complied with, an authorized officer may by written notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: require the holder of an export permit, import permit or possession permit, or a former permit holder (within the meaning of section 33), to provide for inspection a document or record that relates to the compliance with the regulatory requirement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: require a person to provide for inspection a document or record that is required to be kept by the person under a regulatory requirement; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: require a person mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b) to provide further particulars or explanations in respect of a document or record provided by the person.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may make copies, or otherwise record the details, of a document or record provided in compliance with a requirement made under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may retain the document or record for a period that is reasonably necessary for further examination or copying or otherwise recording.

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement made under subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Power to enter non-dwelling premises for ascertaining compliance with regulatory requirement

subsection.leadIn: For ascertaining whether a regulatory requirement has been or is being complied with (purpose of entry), an authorized officer who has reasonable grounds to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: activities for the purpose of exporting or importing Part 1 chemicals or regulated mercury-added products are carried out on any premises; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Part 2 chemicals are kept or used on any premises,

subsection.continued: may, without warrant, during reasonable hours enter the premises to exercise any or all of the powers set out in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not empower an authorized officer to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter any premises that are used wholly or principally for dwelling purposes; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: enter any part of any premises that is a part used wholly or principally for dwelling purposes.

subsection.leadIn: The powers are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to observe and inspect any activity carried out on the premises that the authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe to relate to Part 1 chemicals, Part 2 chemicals or regulated mercury-added products;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: to require the person in charge of the premises to, so far as reasonably practicable, provide for inspection any or all of the following documents or records that are kept on the premises—

subparagraph.content: a document or record prepared under this Ordinance;
a document or record required to be kept under a regulatory requirement;
a document or record containing information about Part 1 chemicals, Part 2 chemicals or regulated mercury-added products;
any other document or record that the authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe to be relevant to the purpose of entry;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to make copies, or otherwise record the details, of a document or record referred to in paragraph (b);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to remove and retain a document or record referred to in paragraph (b) for a period that is reasonably necessary for further examination or copying or otherwise recording;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: to require the person in charge of the premises to, so far as reasonably practicable, provide for inspection any or all of the following things that are kept on the premises—

subparagraph.content: any thing that the authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe to be a Part 1 chemical, Part 2 chemical or regulated mercury-added product (collectively relevant article);
any thing that the authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe to contain a relevant article;
any other thing that the authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe to be relevant to the purpose of entry;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to remove and retain a thing referred to in paragraph (e) for a period that is reasonably necessary for further examination or testing;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to take, free of charge, a sample of a thing referred to in paragraph (e) for examination or testing;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: to take photographs, or make video recordings, of or inside the premises;

paragraph.leadIn: to require the person in charge of the premises to provide further particulars or explanations in respect of—

subparagraph.content: the activities referred to in paragraph (a);
the documents or records referred to in paragraph (b); or
the things referred to in paragraph (e); and

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.leadIn: to require the person in charge of the premises to give any other assistance—

subparagraph.content: that is reasonably necessary to facilitate the authorized officer’s performance of functions under this section; and
that the person is reasonably able to give.

subsection.content: On taking a sample by exercising the power set out in subsection (3)(g), the authorized officer must issue a receipt for the sample to the person in charge of the premises concerned.

A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement made under subsection (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Power to stop and detain

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe that a person has contravened, is contravening or is about to contravene this Ordinance or a regulatory requirement (contravention), the officer may, without warrant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: stop the person (or if the person is in or on any transport, stop and board the transport to stop the person); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: detain the person for a period that is reasonably necessary for an authorized officer to investigate the contravention.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may require a person stopped under subsection (1) to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state the person’s name, contact telephone number and address; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: produce the person’s proof of identity for inspection.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may search a person stopped under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may search the belongings of the person.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not empower an authorized officer to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: board any transport that is used wholly or principally for dwelling purposes; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: enter any part of any transport that is a part used wholly or principally for dwelling purposes.

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement made under subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: proof of identity (身分證明文件) has the meaning given by section 17B(1) of the Immigration Ordinance (Cap. 115).

section.name: s51
section.heading: Power to obtain document and record etc. for investigation

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if an authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: this Ordinance or a regulatory requirement has been, is being or is about to be contravened (contravention); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person has in the person’s control or possession any document, record or information relating to the contravention (evidence).

subsection.leadIn: For investigating the contravention, the authorized officer may require the person to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide the evidence to the officer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide further particulars or explanations in respect of the evidence.

subsection.leadIn: The authorized officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may make copies, or otherwise record the details, of the evidence provided in compliance with a requirement made under subsection (2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may retain the evidence for a period that is reasonably necessary for further examination or testing or copying or otherwise recording.

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement made under subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.
A person is not excused from complying with a requirement made under subsection (2) on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate the person.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Power to retain and seize things etc.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may retain, seize and remove—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any thing in respect of which the officer has reasonable grounds to believe that this Ordinance or a regulatory requirement has been, is being or is about to be contravened (contravention); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any thing that the officer has reasonable grounds to believe to constitute, or to be likely to constitute, evidence of a contravention.

subsection.content: A thing seized or removed under subsection (1) may be retained by an authorized officer for examination or testing.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Power to enter and search premises for investigation

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may issue a warrant if satisfied by information on oath laid by an authorized officer that there are reasonable grounds to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: this Ordinance or a regulatory requirement has been, is being or is about to be contravened (contravention) on any premises; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is, or is likely to be, on any premises any thing that constitutes evidence of a contravention.

subsection.content: A warrant authorizes an authorized officer to enter the premises (and in the case of any transport, stop and board the transport) and exercise any or all of the powers set out in subsection (3) to investigate the contravention.

subsection.leadIn: The powers are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to observe and inspect any activity carried out on the premises that the authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe to relate to Part 1 chemicals, Part 2 chemicals or regulated mercury-added products;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to observe and inspect any process carried out on the premises that the authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe to be a regulated manufacturing process or a process of incorporation referred to in section 15(3);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: to—

subparagraph.content: inspect the premises and search the premises for any document, record, information or any other thing that the authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe to constitute, or to be likely to constitute, evidence of the contravention;
make copies, or otherwise record the details, of the document, record or information;
seize the document, record or thing; and

subparagraph.leadIn: remove and retain the document, record or thing for—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: a period that is reasonably necessary for further examination or testing or copying or otherwise recording; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: a longer period that is necessary for proceedings under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to take photographs, or make video recordings, of or inside the premises;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: to require the person in charge of the premises to provide further particulars or explanations in respect of—

subparagraph.content: the premises;
the activities or processes referred to in paragraph (a) or (b); or
the documents, records, information or things referred to in paragraph (c);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: to require the person in charge of the premises to give any other assistance—

subparagraph.content: that is reasonably necessary to facilitate the authorized officer’s performance of functions under this section; and
that the person is reasonably able to give; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to stop and search a person found on the premises whom the authorized officer has reasonable grounds to believe to have committed, is committing or is about to commit the contravention.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may use reasonably necessary force for gaining entry into the premises; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be accompanied and assisted by any person the officer reasonably requires to perform the function concerned.

subsection.leadIn: A person executing a warrant must, if requested, produce for inspection—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proof of the person’s identity; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the warrant.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Offence relating to section 53

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement made under section 53 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.
A person is not excused from complying with a requirement made under section 53 on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate the person.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Use of incriminating evidence in proceedings

subsection.content: On or before requiring a person to provide any information under section 51 or 53, an authorized officer must ensure that the person is informed or reminded of the limitations imposed by subsection (2) on the admissibility in evidence of the requirement and of the information.

subsection.leadIn: Despite any other provision of this Ordinance, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the authorized officer requires a person to provide any information under section 51 or 53;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the required information might tend to incriminate the person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person claims, before providing the information, that it might so tend,

subsection.continued: the requirement and the information are not admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings in a court of law other than the criminal proceedings specified in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: The criminal proceedings are those in which the person is prosecuted for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence under section 51(4), 54(1) or 63(1) in respect of the information; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offence under Part V of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200) in respect of the information.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: information (資料) includes particulars and explanation.

subdivision.name: SD2
subdivision.heading: Disposal and Forfeiture of Item Seized under Subdivision 1

section.name: s56
section.heading: Interpretation of Subdivision 2 of Division 3 of Part 4
section.def: seized item (檢取物品) means a document, record or thing seized under section 52(1) or 53(3)(c)(iii).

section.name: s57
section.heading: Authorized officer may dispose of certain seized item
section.content: An authorized officer may, in the manner (other than by sale) the officer considers appropriate, dispose of a seized item that is impracticable for the officer to keep.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Disposal of seized item when no offence is prosecuted

subsection.content: This section applies if no offence is prosecuted under this Ordinance in respect of a seized item.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: return the seized item to—

subparagraph.content: if the item was seized from a person—the person or the owner of the item; or
in any other case—the owner of the item; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: forfeit the seized item to the Government if the officer considers it appropriate to do so.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), if the Director intends to forfeit a seized item under subsection (2)(b), the Director must, by written notice, notify the person from whom the item was seized or the owner of the item (collectively interested person) (as the case requires) of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the intention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds for the proposed forfeiture; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the right of the interested person to give a notice of claim under subsection (6) and the period within which such a notice must be given.

subsection.content: The Director is not required to give a notice under subsection (3) in respect of a seized item if the interested person of the item is unknown or cannot be contacted.
If subsection (4) applies, a seized item is to be forfeited to the Government on the expiry of 28 days after the date on which the item is seized.

If the interested person of a seized item objects to the proposed forfeiture of the item to the Government, the person may, within 28 days after the date of the written notice given under subsection (3), give a notice of claim to the Director.

subsection.leadIn: A notice of claim—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is to be in writing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: is to contain—

subparagraph.content: the interested person’s name; and
the interested person’s address for service in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is to state the grounds for objecting to the proposed forfeiture.

subsection.content: If no notice of claim is given in respect of a seized item within the period specified in subsection (6), the item is to be forfeited to the Government on the expiry of the period.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Application for forfeiture

subsection.content: After receiving a notice of claim given within the period specified in section 58(6), the Director must, as soon as reasonably practicable, apply to the court or magistrate (court) for an order that the seized item concerned be forfeited to the Government.

subsection.leadIn: The court may, on the application, order that the seized item—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: be returned to—

subparagraph.content: if the item was seized from a person—the person or the owner of the item; or
in any other case—the owner of the item;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be forfeited to the Government; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be disposed of in another manner it considers appropriate.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Disposal of seized item when offence is prosecuted

subsection.content: This section applies if an offence is prosecuted under this Ordinance in respect of a seized item (irrespective of whether the person prosecuted for the offence is convicted of the offence).

subsection.leadIn: The court or magistrate may, on their own initiative or on application, order that the seized item—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: be returned to—

subparagraph.content: if the item was seized from a person—the person or the owner of the item; or
in any other case—the owner of the item;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be forfeited to the Government; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be disposed of in another manner it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (2) may only be made by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an authorized officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person from whom the item was seized; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the owner of the item.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Disposal of item forfeited to Government

subsection.content: An authorized officer may dispose of an item forfeited under section 58(5) or (8) or by an order under section 59(2)(b) or 60(2)(b) in the manner the officer considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: The cost incurred in disposing of an item forfeited by an order under section 59(2)(b) or 60(2)(b) is recoverable as a civil debt due to the Government from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for an item forfeited by an order under section 59(2)(b)—the person from whom the item was seized or the owner of the item (as the case requires); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for an item forfeited by an order under section 60(2)(b)—the person prosecuted for an offence in respect of the item under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Without limiting subsection (1), an authorized officer may, by written notice, require a person who is convicted of an offence under this Ordinance in respect of an item forfeited by an order under section 60(2)(b) to dispose of the item in the manner specified by the officer at the person’s cost.
A person who fails to comply with a requirement made under subsection (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Compensation for seizure etc.

subsection.leadIn: The Government is liable to compensate the owner of a seized item for any loss suffered by the owner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: because of the seizure; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: because of the loss of, or damage to, the item during the seizure or retention.

subsection.content: However, for an item forfeited by an order under section 59(2)(b) or 60(2)(b), the owner of the item is entitled to compensation under subsection (1) only if the order was made because the owner was unknown, or could not be contacted, at the time the order was made.

In any proceedings against the Government in respect of a claim for compensation under subsection (1), the amount of compensation recoverable is an amount that is just and equitable in all the circumstances of the case.

subsection.leadIn: The circumstances referred to in subsection (3) include the conduct and comparative blameworthiness of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner of the seized item;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person from whom the item was seized;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the employees or agents, if any, of a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Director and other persons concerned.

subsection.leadIn: Proceedings in respect of a claim for compensation may be commenced—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a claim on the ground specified in subsection (1)(a)—within 6 months after the date on which the item concerned is seized; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a claim on the ground specified in subsection (1)(b)—within 6 months after the earlier of the following—

subparagraph.content: the date on which the owner of the seized item discovered the loss or damage;
the date on which the owner could, with reasonable diligence, have discovered the loss or damage.

subsection.leadIn: A claim for compensation under subsection (1) is to be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a claim within the jurisdiction of the Small Claims Tribunal—in the Small Claims Tribunal or District Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: otherwise—in the District Court.

part.name: P5
part.heading: Miscellaneous Offences and Other Matters relating to Offences

section.name: s63
section.heading: Provision of false or misleading information etc.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the person provides any information to a public officer—

subparagraph.content: for the purpose of an application under this Ordinance; or
in purported compliance with a regulatory requirement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the information is false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the information is false or misleading in that material particular.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: information (資料) includes document, record, particulars and explanation.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Obstruction of public officer etc.

subsection.content: A person must not wilfully obstruct a public officer who is performing a function under this Ordinance.
A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Prosecution deadline for offence under section 63(1)
section.leadIn: A prosecution for an offence under section 63(1) may only be started before the earlier of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the end of 2 years beginning on the date on which the offence is committed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the end of 6 months beginning on the date on which the offence is discovered by, or comes to the notice of, the Director.

section.content: This replaces the time limit under section 26 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227).

section.name: s66
section.heading: Liability of officer of body corporate, partner and member of unincorporated body

subsection.leadIn: If a body corporate commits an offence under this Ordinance, and it is proved that the offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was committed with the consent or connivance of a person specified in subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is attributable to any neglect on the part of the person,

subsection.continued: the person also commits the offence.

subsection.leadIn: The person referred to in subsection (1) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person purporting to act in the capacity of a person referred to in paragraph (a).

subsection.leadIn: If a partner in a partnership commits an offence under this Ordinance, and it is proved that the offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was committed with the consent or connivance of a person specified in subsection (4); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is attributable to any neglect on the part of the person,

subsection.continued: the person also commits the offence.

subsection.leadIn: The person referred to in subsection (3) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a partner, or an office holder, in the partnership;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person concerned in the management of the partnership; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person purporting to act in the capacity of a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

subsection.leadIn: If a member of an unincorporated body of persons (other than a partnership) commits an offence under this Ordinance, and it is proved that the offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was committed with the consent or connivance of a person specified in subsection (6); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is attributable to any neglect on the part of the person,

subsection.continued: the person also commits the offence.

subsection.leadIn: The person referred to in subsection (5) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a member, or a manager, secretary or other similar officer, of the unincorporated body;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person concerned in the management of the unincorporated body; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person purporting to act in the capacity of a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

section.name: s67
section.heading: Employer’s liability for employee’s act

subsection.content: An act done or omission made by an employee in the course of employment is to be regarded for the purposes of this Ordinance as done or made by the employer, as well as by the employee.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance brought against an employer in respect of an act or omission alleged to have been done or made by an employee, it is a defence for the employer to establish that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the act was done or the omission was made without the employer’s knowledge and consent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the employer had taken all reasonable steps to prevent the employee from—

subparagraph.content: doing the act or making the omission; or
doing an act or making an omission of that description in the course of the employee’s employment.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Taking reasonable steps etc. is defence

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person (defendant) prosecuted for an offence under this Ordinance to establish—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that the act or omission in respect of which the offence is prosecuted was done or made by the defendant—

subparagraph.content: under the instruction of the defendant’s employer;

because of the defendant’s reliance on the information given by a third person, and at the time of the alleged offence the defendant did not know, and had no reason to believe, that the information was false or misleading; or
because of another act or omission of a third person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the defendant had taken all reasonable steps, and had exercised all due diligence, to prevent the commission of the offence.

subsection.leadIn: If a defendant intends to establish a defence on the ground referred to in subsection (1)(a)(ii) or (iii), the defendant must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: obtain the leave of the court or magistrate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give a notice in accordance with subsection (3) to the person bringing the proceedings for the offence concerned.

subsection.leadIn: A notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is to be in writing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: is to contain the information—

subparagraph.content: that is about the identity of the third person concerned; and
that is in the defendant’s control or possession; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is to be given at least 7 days before the commencement of the hearing of the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: third person (第三者), in relation to a defendant, means a person other than—(a)the defendant’s employer;(b)the defendant’s employee; or(c)any other employee of the defendant’s employer.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Reasonable excuse
section.content: If a provision of this Ordinance that creates an offence refers to a reasonable excuse for a contravention of the provision, the reference is to be construed as providing a defence for a person prosecuted for the offence.

section.name: s70
section.heading: How to establish defence

subsection.content: This section applies if a provision of this Ordinance provides a defence for a person prosecuted for an offence under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: A person prosecuted for an offence under this Ordinance is to be regarded as having established a matter that needs to be established for the defence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue with respect to the matter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Secretary and Director may delegate function

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may delegate the function conferred on the Secretary under section 76 to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a public officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a member of a class of public officers.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may delegate any function conferred on the Director under this Ordinance (other than this section or section 72) to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a public officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a member of a class of public officers.

subsection.leadIn: A delegation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is to be in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: may be made in relation to—

subparagraph.content: specified provisions of this Ordinance; or
this Ordinance generally.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Director may authorize public officer etc.

subsection.content: The Director may authorize a public officer, or a member of a class of public officers, to be an authorized officer for the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: An authorization—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is to be in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: may be given in relation to—

subparagraph.content: specified provisions of this Ordinance; or
this Ordinance generally.

subsection.content: The Director may perform any function of an authorized officer under this Ordinance.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Proof of identity etc.
section.content: When performing a function under this Ordinance, a public officer must produce proof of the officer’s identity for inspection by a person who is affected by the performance of the function and requests to see it.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Requirement made under this Ordinance
section.content: If a requirement is made by a public officer under this Ordinance, the officer must, in the requirement, specify the manner in which, and the period within which, the requirement is to be complied with.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Director may specify form

subsection.content: The Director may specify the form of a document required for the purposes of this Ordinance.
In specifying the form of a document, the Director may specify more than one form of the document, whether as alternatives or for use in different circumstances.
A form specified under this section is to be completed in accordance with the directions specified in the form.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Secretary may exempt public officer

subsection.content: The Secretary may, either generally or in a particular case, exempt a public officer (or a member of a class of public officers) from a provision of this Ordinance.
An exemption is to be in writing.

subsection.leadIn: An exemption—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is in force for the period specified by the Secretary; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is subject to the conditions the Secretary considers appropriate.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Secretary may amend Schedule
section.content: The Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 1, 2, 3 or 4.

section.name: s78
section.heading: Secretary may make regulation

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may make regulations for one or more of the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to implement (whether in whole or in part) a provision of the Convention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to require fees to be paid in relation to any matter provided for under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to provide for incidental, supplemental, evidential, consequential, savings and transitional provisions that are necessary and expedient in consequence of a regulation made under this section;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to provide generally for the better carrying out of the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: A regulation made under this section that implements a provision of the Convention may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: set out or refer directly to the provision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the amendments, modifications or adaptations subject to which the provision is to have effect.

subsection.leadIn: A regulation made under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may prescribe offences for contravention of a regulation, punishable by a fine, imprisonment or both; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may provide for defences to such offences.

subsection.content: The maximum penalty that may be prescribed by a regulation made under this section for an offence is a fine at level 3 and imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Prescribed fee
